poem:
**Battle Wookie**

In the unforeseen dance  
of turning centuries,  
a garage track emerges—  
plucked from the seams  
of Freeez in the 80s.  
It hums with a bassline  
that recalls a country  
glowingly on the cusp,  
where memories mix  
with vinyl whispers.  
Here, a new tune taps  
into the perpetual  
pulse of progression.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Someone compared it to Bohemian Rhapsody’: Wookie on making UK garage classic Battle Wookie, producer People say Battle reminds them of some really good years for Britain as a country. We were entering a new millennium, everyone was running their own business, making money and the underground record industry was thriving. I wanted to do a UK garage version of Southern Freeez, by the 80s UK funk band Freeez. Initially, Battle was going to be". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
